description: The musical “Solitary Light,” in the Theater: Village festival, touches on the 1911 Triangle garment factory fire that killed scores of garment workers.
title: ‘Solitary Light,’ by Axis Theater, on Triangle Factory Fire
title_page: ‘Solitary Light,’ by Axis Theater, on Triangle Factory Fire - The New York Times
maintext:
The occasional hints of character development glimmer through, along with feints at politics (though the politics, revolving largely around young women looking for love and mooning over products like turn-of-the-century Material Girls, are tediously predictable). And there is a soupçon of philosophy about the camera and the nature of time.
The music (live with recorded augmentation, written by Ms. Sharp and Paul Carbonara) is fine — think of a briskly emotional and not unpleasing Disney soundtrack — and several performers are strong. Shira Averbuch, possessed of a winning voice and an enigmatically expressive smile, is a particular relief as the romantic lead.
But really there isn’t much the cast can do with this production. It’s maddeningly soupy: theatrical insult to historical injury.
